title: Neural Lyapunov Model Predictive Control: Learning Safe Global Controllers from Sub-optimal Examples

Problem (III-B) is solved online given the current state xâ€‹(t)ğ‘¥ğ‘¡x(t); then, the first element of the optimal control sequence, uâ‹†â€‹(0)superscriptğ‘¢â‹†0u^{\star}(0), provides the action for the physical system. Then, a new state is measured, and (III-B) is again solved, in a receding horizon.
The implementation details are given in Appendix. We extend standard results from [ref]20  to the discounted case and to the Î»ğœ†\lambda-contractive Vğ‘‰V from (5). In order to prove them, we make use of the uniform continuity of the model, the SQP solution and the terminal cost, Vğ‘‰V, as done by .

Theorem 2 states that for a given horizon Nğ‘N and contraction Î»ğœ†\lambda, one can find a minimum scaling of the Lyapunov function Vğ‘‰V and a lower bound on the discount factor Î³ğ›¾\gamma such that the system under the MPC has ROA Î¥_â€‹N,Î³,Î±âŠ‡ğ•_â€‹ssubscriptğ•_ğ‘ subscriptÎ¥_ğ‘ğ›¾ğ›¼\Upsilon_{\_}{N,\gamma,\alpha}\supseteq\mathbb{X}_{\_}s. If the model is not perfect, its error being less than Î¼â‰¤Î¼Â¯ğœ‡Â¯ğœ‡\mu\leq\bar{\mu}, then the ROA size decreases but the system is still safe. In this case, a shorter horizon can be beneficial.
The proof of the theorem follows standard MPC arguments and is in Appendix. In order to further motivate for the search of a Vğ‘‰V giving the largest ğ•_â€‹ssubscriptğ•_ğ‘ \mathbb{X}_{\_}s, notice that a larger ğ•_â€‹ssubscriptğ•_ğ‘ \mathbb{X}_{\_}s can allow for shortening the MPC horizon, possibly yielding the same ROA. Contrary to , we demonstrate how model mismatch and longer horizons can decrease performance with respect to an infinite-horizon oracle with same cost and perfect model. This links RL to arguments used in nominal MPC robustness  [ref]25. Performance
Assume that the value function error is bounded for all xğ‘¥x, namely, â€–Vâ‹†â€‹(x)âˆ’Î±â€‹Vâ€‹(x)â€–_â€‹22â‰¤Ïµsubscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘‰â‹†ğ‘¥ğ›¼ğ‘‰ğ‘¥_superscript22italic-Ïµ\|V^{\star}(x)-\alpha V(x)\|_{\_}2^{2}\leq\epsilon, and that the model error satisfies (8), for some Î¼>0ğœ‡0\mu>0.
Then, for any Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0: where LÂ¯_â€‹f=minâ¡(L_â€‹f^â€‹x,L_â€‹fâ€‹x)subscriptÂ¯ğ¿_ğ‘“subscriptğ¿_^ğ‘“ğ‘¥subscriptğ¿_ğ‘“ğ‘¥\bar{L}_{\_}{f}=\min(L_{\_}{\hat{f}x},L_{\_}{{f}x}) and ÏˆÂ¯Â¯ğœ“\bar{\psi} is a ğ’¦_â€‹âˆsubscriptğ’¦_\mathcal{K}_{\_}\infty-function representing the constraint penalty terms. Theorem 3 is related to  for value-based RL. However, here we do not constrain the system and model to be stable, nor assume the MPC optimal cost to be Lipschitz. Theorem 3 shows that a discount Î³ğ›¾\gamma or a shorter horizon Nğ‘N can mitigate model errors. Since Î³â‰ª1much-less-thanğ›¾1\gamma\ll 1 can limit stability (Theorem 2) we opt for the shortest horizon, hence N=1ğ‘1N=1, Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1. Proof of Theorem 3 is in Appendix. The stability bounds discussed in Theorem 2 can be conservative and their computation is non-trivial. Theoretically, the bigger the Î±ğ›¼\alpha the larger is the ROA (the safe region) for the MPC, up to its maximum extent. Practically, for a very high Î±ğ›¼\alpha, the MPC solver may not converge due to ill-conditioning.
Initially, by using the tool from [ref]27 within an SQP scheme, we tried to tune the parameters through gradient-based optimization of the lossÂ (10). These attempts were not successful, as expected from the considerations in . Therefore, for practical reasons, in this work we perform a grid search over the MPC parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha. Note that the discount factor Î³ğ›¾\gamma is mainly introduced for Theorem 3 and analysed in Theorem 2 to allow for future combination of stable MPC with value iteration.
